[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: as_noise_network_address()] [Public Key Substitution] Between storing the public_key in the constructor and using it in as_noise_network_address(), can a race condition or concurrent modification allow an attacker to substitute a different public key? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Struct: NodeAddress] [Cookie Store Race Condition] The cookie_store is Arc<Jar> shared across multiple clients - can concurrent access from multiple threads cause race conditions in cookie reading/writing, leading to authentication bypass or session confusion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_metrics_client()] [Cookie Leakage] The same cookie_store (line 98) is used for both metrics and API clients - can cookies intended for the API endpoint (potentially with authentication) leak to the metrics endpoint or vice versa? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_api_client()] [Cookie Persistence] Are cookies persisted across NodeAddress clones? Since cookie_store is Arc, cloning NodeAddress shares the same Jar - can this cause unintended cookie sharing between different node connections? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Struct: NodeAddress] [Cookie Store Initialization] The cookie_store is initialized with Jar::default() which is empty - but can an attacker exploit the lack of HttpOnly, Secure, or SameSite flags in cookies accepted by this Jar? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: Clone] [Cookie Store Cloning] When NodeAddress is cloned (derived Clone trait), the Arc<Jar> is shallow-copied - can this lead to unexpected cookie sharing between supposedly independent node connections, causing authentication confusion? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Struct: NodeAddress] [Cookie Injection] Since the cookie_store is shared and skipped in serialization (line 33), can a deserialized NodeAddress have its cookie store manipulated by an attacker before it's used for requests? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_metrics_client()] [Timeout Bypass] The timeout parameter is user-controlled - can an attacker set an extremely large Duration to cause requests to hang indefinitely, blocking threads and exhausting resources? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_api_client()] [Timeout Race Condition] If timeout is very small (e.g., Duration::from_millis(1)), can it cause race conditions where legitimate responses are rejected while attacks slip through? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_metrics_client()] [Client Reuse] Each call creates a new reqwest::Client - can this exhaust connection pools or file descriptors if called repeatedly in a loop? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_api_client()] [TLS Configuration] The HTTP clients don't explicitly configure TLS settings - can an attacker exploit weak ciphers, missing certificate validation, or accept self-signed certificates to perform MITM attacks? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_api_client()] [Redirect Following] Does reqwest::Client follow redirects by default? If so, can an attacker redirect API/metrics requests to malicious servers or internal endpoints? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/configuration/node_address.rs] [Function: get_metrics_url()] [Unwrap Panic] The set_port() call uses unwrap() on line 89 - can this panic with special URL types (opaque URLs, mailto:, etc.) that don't support ports? (High)
